revision.comment: link [[Right to privacy|privacy violation]] using [[:en:User:Edward/Find link|Find link]]
revision.text:
{{Redirect|Binner|the surname|Binner (surname)}} {{Redirect|Trashers|the ice hockey team|Danbury Trashers}} {{Redirect|Dumpster diver|the bird|Australian white ibis}} [[File:ROYAL food, NY.jpg|thumb|A person dumpster diving]] [[File:Poor men and children scavenge the trash dumps of Kabul's neighborhoods for leftovers and recyclable materials..webm|thumb|right|Video of impoverished individuals "dumpster diving" at a neighborhood trash dump in [[Kabul]]]]
'''Dumpster diving''' (also '''totting''',<ref name="HSE">{{cite web |url=http://www.hseni.gov.uk/waste18.pdf |title=Hand sorting of recyclables ('totting') with vehicle assistance |date=May 2012 |publisher=[[Health & Safety Executive]] |access-date=10 January 2016 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120817205956/http://www.hseni.gov.uk/waste18.pdf |archivedate=17 August 2012 }}</ref> '''skipping''',<ref>{{cite book |last1=Boisseau |first1=Will |last2=Donaghey |first2=Jim |chapter=“Nailing Descartes to the wall”: Animal rights, veganism and punk culture |editor-last=Nocella |editor-first=Anthony |title=Anarchism and animal liberation : Essays on complementary elements of total liberation |publisher=McFarland & Company |publication-place=Jefferson, North Carolina |year=2015 |isbn=978-0-7864-9457-6 |oclc=913784877 |chapter-url=https://www.academia.edu/download/39339240/Boisseau___Donaghey_Nailing_Descartes_To_The_Wall.pdf#page=19 |p=85}}</ref> '''skip diving''' or '''skip salvage''',<ref name="Lewycka">{{cite news|url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23714626-so-im-a-skip-addict---avocado-bath-suite-anyone.do|title=So, I'm a skip addict - avocado bath suite, anyone?|last=Lewycka|first=Marina|date=2 July 2009|work=London Evening Standard|accessdate=2009-10-31|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606125740/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23714626-so-im-a-skip-addict---avocado-bath-suite-anyone.do|archivedate=6 June 2011}}</ref><ref name="Issue 561">{{cite news|url=http://www.schnews.org.uk/archive/news561.htm|title=Issue 561|date=22 September 2006|publisher=SchNEWS|accessdate=2009-11-11|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091015140753/http://www.schnews.org.uk/archive/news561.htm|archive-date=15 October 2009|url-status=dead}}</ref>) is [[salvaging]] from large commercial, residential, industrial and construction containers for unused items discarded by their owners, but deemed useful to the picker. It is not confined to [[dumpster]]s and [[skip (container)|skip]]s specifically, and may cover standard household waste containers, curb sides, landfills or small dumps.
Different terms are used to refer to different forms of this activity. For picking materials from the [[curbside trash collection]], expressions such as '''curb shopping''', '''trash picking''' or '''street scavenging''' are sometimes used.<ref>{{cite book |last=Ferrell |first=Jeff |date=2005 |title=Empire of Scrounge: Inside the Urban Underground of Dumpster Diving, Trash Picking, and Street Scavenging |publisher=New York University Press |isbn=978-0-81472-738-6}}</ref> When seeking primarily metal to be recycled, one is '''scrapping'''. When picking the leftover food from traditional or industrial farming left in the fields one is '''gleaning'''.
People dumpster dive for items such as clothing, furniture, food, and similar items in good working condition.<ref name="Dos">{{cite web|url=http://wildernesssurvivaltechniques.com/the-dos-and-donts-of-dumpster-diving/|title=The Do's and Don'ts of Dumpster Diving|last=Admin|website=Wilderness Survival Techniques|accessdate=9 March 2012}}</ref> Some people do this out of necessity due to [[poverty]],<ref name="Rufus & Lawson"/> while others do so professionally and systematically for profit.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wired.com/2015/02/high-end-dumpster-diving-matt-malone/ |title=The Pro Dumpster Diver Who's Making Thousands Off America's Biggest Retailers |website=[[wired (magazine)|Wired]] |author=Randall Sullivan |date=February 3, 2015 |accessdate=March 31, 2015 |quote=his claim that he can make a quarter-million dollars a year from trash}}</ref>
== Etymology == <!-- Please cite alternative terms with a reliable source --> The term "dumpster diving" emerged in the 1980s, combining "diving" with "[[dumpster]]", a large commercial [[trash bin]].<ref name=OEDdumpsterdiving>{{cite encyclopedia |encyclopedia= [[Oxford English Encyclopedia]] |title= dumpster diving, n |url= http://www.oed.com/view/Entry/258481?redirectedFrom=dumpster+diving& |access-date= September 17, 2015 |year= 1993 |publisher= University of Oxford Press}}</ref> The term "Dumpster" itself comes from the Dempster Dumpster, a brand of bins manufactured by Dempster Brothers beginning in 1937. "Dumpster" became [[generic trademark|genericized]] by the 1970s.<ref name=OEDDumpster>{{cite encyclopedia |encyclopedia= [[Oxford English Dictionary]] |title= dumpster, n |url= http://www.oed.com/view/Entry/242635#eid12613926 |access-date= September 17, 2015 |year= 1993 |publisher= University of Oxford Press}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=The New Oxford American Dictionary|editor=Erin McKean|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2005|edition= second|isbn=978-0-19-517077-1}}</ref> According to the ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'', the term "dumpster diving" is chiefly found in [[American English]] and first appeared in print in 1983, with the verb "dumpster-dive" appearing a few years later.<ref name="OEDdumpsterdiving"/> In [[British English]], the practice may be known as "skipping", from [[Skip (container)|skip]], another term for this type of container.<ref name="Lewycka"/><ref name="Issue 561"/><ref>{{cite encyclopedia |encyclopedia= [[Oxford English Dictionary]] |title= skip, n.2 |url= http://www.oed.com/view/Entry/180963?rskey=tdddnG&result=2#eid |access-date= September 17, 2015 |year= 1993 |publisher= University of Oxford Press}}</ref>
Alternative names for the practice include bin-diving,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/wordofmouth/2007/aug/17/wastenotwantnot |title= Why I love bin diving |first= Alex |last= Renton |date=August 17, 2007 |work=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=November 28, 2009 | location=London}}</ref> containering,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,4881647,00.html |title=Dumpster diving stays on trend in Germany |publisher=Dw-world.de |accessdate=30 January 2014}}</ref> D-mart,<ref>{{cite web|author=Niki D'Andrea |url=http://www.phoenixnewtimes.com/2009-08-20/news/dumpster-dining-for-freegans-eating-garbage-is-getting-downright-trendy/ |title=Dumpster Dining: For Freegans, Eating Garbage Is Getting Downright Trendy - Page 1 - News - Phoenix |website=Phoenix New Times |date=2012-08-30 |accessdate=2012-09-07}}</ref> dumpstering,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tampabay.com/features/consumer/article451134.ece |title=One man's trash is another man's ... lunch ≤or software treat≥ |first=Dalia |last= Colon |date= April 11, 2008 |website=[[St. Petersburg Times]] |accessdate=November 28, 2009}}</ref> totting,<ref name=HSE/> and skipping.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cultureunplugged.com/play/6316/Skipping-Dinner |title=Skipping Diner |year=2010 |accessdate=2012-09-11}}</ref> In Australia, garbage picking is called "skip dipping."
== Participants == [[Image:Man rummaging thought a skip.jpg|thumb|A man rummaging through a [[skip (container)|skip]] at the back of an [[office]] building in [[Central London]]]] The term "binner" is often used to describe individuals who collect recyclable materials for their deposit value. For example, in [[Vancouver]], British Columbia, binners, or bottle collectors, search garbage cans and dumpsters for [[recycling|recyclable materials]] that can be redeemed for their [[Deposit-refund system|deposit value]]. On average, these binners earn about $40 a day for several garbage bags full of discarded containers.<ref>{{cite news | first = Emily | last = Jackson | title = Vancouver fireworks a boon for city | date = 2010-07-28 | url = https://vancouversun.com/Vancouver+fireworks+boon+city+bottle+collectors/3334521/story.html | work = The Vancouver Sun | accessdate = 2010-08-04}}</ref>
The [[karung guni]], [[Zabbaleen]], the [[rag and bone man]], [[waste picker]], [[junk man]] or bin hoker are terms for people who make their living by sorting and trading trash. A similar process known as [[gleaning]] was practised in rural areas and some ancient agricultural societies, where the residue from farmers' fields was collected.
Some dumpster divers, who self-identify as [[Freeganism|freegan]]s, aim to reduce their [[ecological footprint]] by living from dumpster-dived-goods,<ref name="Mansvelt"/> sometimes exclusively.
== Overview == The activity is performed by people out of necessity in the developing world.<ref name="Rufus & Lawson"/> Some scavengers perform in organized groups, and some organize on various internet forums and social networking websites.<ref name="Rufus & Lawson"/> By [[Reuse|reusing]], or repurposing, resources destined for the [[landfill]], dumpster diving is sometimes considered to be an [[Environmentalism|environmentalist]] endeavor,<ref name="Mansvelt"/> and is thus practiced by many pro-green communities. The wastefulness of consumer society and throw-away culture compels some individuals to rescue usable items (for example, computers or [[smartphones]], which are frequently discarded due to the extensive use of [[planned obsolescence]] in the technology industry) from destruction<ref name="Mansvelt"/> and divert them to those who can make use of the items.
A wide variety of things may be disposed while still repairable or in working condition, making salvage of them a source of potentially free items for personal use, or to sell for profit. Irregular, blemished or damaged items that are still otherwise functional are regularly thrown away. [[Food waste|Discarded food]] that might have slight imperfections, near its [[shelf life|expiration date]], or that is simply being replaced by newer stock is often tossed out despite being still edible.<ref name="Mansvelt"/> Many retailers are reluctant to sell this stock at reduced prices because of the risks that people will buy it instead of the higher-priced newer stock, that extra handling time is required, and that there are [[Public liability|liability]] risks. In the [[United Kingdom]], cookery books have been written on the cooking and consumption of such foods, which has contributed to the popularity of skipping.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} Artists often use discarded materials retrieved from trash receptacles to create works of [[found objects]] or [[assemblage (art)|assemblage]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A31130-2004Nov6.html|title=Get Your Mind Into the Gutter|last=Sachs|first=Andrea|date=7 November 2004|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=20 January 2010}}</ref>
Students have been known to partake in dumpster diving to obtain high tech items for technical projects, or simply to indulge their curiosity for unusual items.<ref>{{Cite news|title = Dumpster Diving|first = Cyndeth|last = Allison|newspaper = North Denver News|date = 8 May 2007|url = http://northdenvernews.com/content/view/766/2/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071103000805/http://northdenvernews.com/content/view/766/2/|archivedate=November 3, 2007|postscript = <!-- None -->}}</ref> Dumpster diving can additionally be used in support of academic research. Garbage picking serves as the main tool for [[garbology|garbologist]]s, who study the [[sociology]] and [[archeology]] of trash in modern life. Private and government investigators may pick through garbage to obtain information for their inquiries. Illegal cigarette consumption may be deduced from discarded packages.
Dumpster diving can be hazardous, due to potential exposure to [[Biological hazard|biohazardous]] matter, broken glass, and overall unsanitary conditions that may exist in dumpsters.<ref name="Rufus & Lawson"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/dec/28/amazon-dumpster-death-homeless-man-frank-ryan|title=Death in an Amazon dumpster|first=Alastair|last=Gee|date=28 December 2017|publisher=|access-date=28 January 2018|via=www.TheGuardian.com}}</ref>
Arguments against garbage picking often focus on the health and cleanliness implications of people rummaging in trash.{{citation needed|date=January 2015}} This exposes the dumpster divers to potential health risks, and, especially if the dumpster diver does not return the non-usable items to their previous location, may leave trash scattered around. Divers can also be seriously injured or killed by garbage collection vehicles; in January 2012, in [[La Jolla]], Swiss-American man [[Alfonso de Bourbon]] was killed by a truck while dumpster diving.<ref name="LJL">{{cite news|url=http://www.lajollalight.com/2012/01/12/victim-in-alleyway-dumpster-death-identified-as-alfonso-de-bourbon-83/|title=Victim in alleyway dumpster death identified as Alfonso de Bourbon, 83|publisher=La Jolla Light|date=11 January 2012|last=Schwab|first=Dave|access-date=30 January 2014|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140220053609/http://www.lajollalight.com/2012/01/12/victim-in-alleyway-dumpster-death-identified-as-alfonso-de-bourbon-83/|archivedate=20 February 2014}}</ref> Further, there are also concerns around the legality of taking items that may still technically belong to the person who threw them away (or to the waste management operator), and whether the taking of some items like discarded documents is a [[Privacy laws of the United States|violation of privacy]]. In general a legal concept called abandonment of property covers this question of the subject of ownership of property that is disposed of.{{citation needed|date=December 2018}}
Discarded billing records may be used for [[identity theft]]. As a [[privacy violation]], discarded medical records as trash led to a $140,000 penalty against Massachusetts billing company Goldthwait Associates and a group of pathology offices in 2013<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/whitecoatnotes/2013/01/07/doctors-billing-company-pay-penalty-for-records-tossed-public-dump/FDGSf172lyc2xasT6D0DRM/story.html|title=Doctors, billing company pay $140,000 penalty for records tossed in public dump|website=Boston Globe|accessdate=30 March 2015}}</ref> and a $400,000 settlement between Midwest Women's Healthcare Specialists and 1,532 clients in Kansas City in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kansascity.com/news/local/article4279093.html|title=Settlement reached in medical billing records case|website=kansascity|accessdate=30 March 2015}}</ref>
== Legal status == Since dumpsters are usually located on private premises, divers may occasionally get in trouble for [[trespassing]] while dumpster diving, though the law is enforced with varying degrees of rigor.<ref name="Mansvelt"/> Some businesses may lock dumpsters to prevent pickers from congregating on their property, vandalism to their property, and to limit potential liability if a dumpster diver is injured while on their property.<ref name="Mansvelt"/>
[[Police]] searches of discarded waste as well as similar methods are also generally not considered violations; [[evidence (law)|evidence]] [[Search and seizure|seized]] in this manner has been permitted in many [[criminal procedure|criminal trials]]. In the United States this has been affirmed by numerous courts including and up to the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]], in the decision ''[[California v. Greenwood]]''. The doctrine is not as well established in regards to [[civil litigation]].{{citation needed|date=August 2015}}
Companies run by private investigators specializing in such techniques have emerged as a result of the need for discreet, undetected retrieval of documents and evidence for civil and criminal trials. Private investigators have also written books on "P.I. technique" in which dumpster diving or its equivalent "wastebasket recovery" figures prominently.
=== By country === In 2009, a Belgian dumpster diver and eco-activist nicknamed Ollie was detained for a month for removing food from a garbage can, and was accused of theft and burglary. On February 25, 2009, he was arrested for removing food from a garbage can at an [[Delhaize Group|AD Delhaize]] supermarket in Bruges. Ollie's trial evoked protests in Belgium against restrictions from taking discarded food items.<ref>{{cite web|author=Auteur: Arne Franck |url=http://www.standaard.be/Artikel/Detail.aspx?artikelId=PH276CR6 |title=De Standaard: Arrogante houding houdt voedseldief in de cel |publisher=Standaard.be |accessdate=2009-05-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://indymedia.nl/nl/2009/03/57978.shtml |title=Update Skipper in de Brugse gevangenis |publisher=Indymedia NL |accessdate=2009-05-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indymedia.be/en/node/32078 |title=Lawaaidemo voor Ollie aan de poorten van de Burgse gevangenis |publisher=Indymedia.be |date=2009-03-05 |accessdate=2009-05-07}}</ref>
In [[Ontario]], Canada, the ''[[Trespass to Property Act (Ontario)|Trespass to Property Act]]''—legislation dating back to the [[Constitution Act, 1867|''British North America Act'' of 1867]]<ref name="wired509"/>—grants property owners and security guards the power to ban anyone from their premises, for any reason, permanently. This is done by issuing a notice to the intruder, who will only be breaking the law upon return.<ref>{{cite canlaw|short title=Trespass to Property Act|abbr=RSO|year=1990|chapter=T.21|section=3|subsection=1|link=http://www.canlii.org/en/on/laws/stat/rso-1990-c-t21/latest/rso-1990-c-t21.html|linkloc=CanLII|wikilink=Trespass to Property Act of Ontario}}</ref> Similar laws exist in [[Prince Edward Island]] and [[Saskatchewan]].<ref>{{cite canlaw|short title=Trespass to Property Act|abbr=RSPEI|year=1988|chapter=T-6|section=2|subsection=2|link=http://www.canlii.org/en/pe/laws/stat/rspei-1988-c-t-6/latest/rspei-1988-c-t-6.html|linkloc=CanLII}}</ref><ref>{{cite canlaw|short title=The Trespass to Property Act|abbr=SS|year=2009|chapter=T-20.2|section=11|link=http://www.canlii.org/en/sk/laws/stat/ss-2009-c-t-20.2/latest/ss-2009-c-t-20.2.html|linkloc=CanLII}}</ref> A recent case in Canada, which involved a police officer who retrieved a discarded weapon from a trash receptacle as evidence, created some controversy. The judge ruled the policeman's actions as legal although there was no warrant present, which led some to speculate the event as validation for any Canadian citizen to raid garbage disposals.<ref name="wired509">{{cite web|author=Cory Doctorow |url=https://www.wired.com/wired/archive/5.09/es_dumpster.html |title=Wired 5.09: Dumpster Diving |website=Wired |accessdate=2009-05-07}}</ref>
Skipping in England and Wales may qualify as theft within the [[Theft Act 1968]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Theft Act 1968|url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1968/60|publisher=legislation.gov.uk}}</ref>{{original research inline|date=October 2015}} or as common-law theft in [[Scotland]], though there is very little enforcement in practice.
In Germany, dumpster diving is referred to as "containern",<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3dR8BAAAQBAJ&pg=PA139 | title=Politische Mahlzeiten. Political Meals | publisher=LIT Verlag Münster | year=2014 | pages=139 | isbn=978-3643126887}}</ref> and a waste container's contents are regarded as the property of the container's owner. Therefore, taking items from such a container is viewed as theft. However, the police will routinely disregard the illegality of garbage picking since the items found are generally of low value. There has only been one known instance where people were prosecuted.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Malkus|first=Max|date=2016|year=|title=Containern – strafbar und strafwürdig?|url=http://www.magazin-restkultur.de/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/MGZNRK_MaxMalkus-Containern-strafbar-strafwuerdig_.pdf|journal=Magazin für Restkultur|volume=4/2016|pages= 2|via=|doi-access=}}</ref> In 2009 individuals were arrested on assumed burglary as they had surmounted a supermarket's fence which was then followed by a theft complaint by the owner; the case was suspended.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.taz.de/pt/2004/12/21/a0047.nf/text |title=Archiv |website=die Tageszeitung |accessdate=2009-05-07}}</ref>
In the United States, the 1988 ''[[California v. Greenwood]]'' case in the [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]] held that there is no [[common law]] [[expectation of privacy]] for [[post-consumer waste|discarded materials]].<ref>{{ussc|name=California v. Greenwood|volume=486|page=35|year=1988|pin=40}}</ref> There are, however, limits to what can legally be taken from a company's refuse. In a 1983 [[Minnesota]] case involving the theft of customer lists from a garbage can, ''Tennant Company v. Advance Machine Company'' (355 N.W.2d 720), the owner of the discarded information was awarded $500,000 in damages.<ref>{{cite web|title=TENNANT CO. v. ADVANCE MACH. CO., INC. 355 N.W.2d 720 (1984)|url=http://www.leagle.com/xmlResult.aspx?xmldoc=19841075355NW2d720_2994.xml&docbase=CSLWAR1-1950-1985}}</ref>
== Items == {{Refimprove section|date=February 2010}} [[File:Dumpster diving Linkoping.jpg|thumb|Food obtained by dumpster diving in [[Linköping]], [[Sweden]]]]
Dumpster diving is practiced differently in developed countries than in developing countries.
* '''Food'''. In many developing countries, food is rarely thrown away unless it is rotten as food is scarce in comparison to developed nations. In countries like the United States, where 40 to 50 percent of food is wasted, the trash contains a lot more food to gather.<ref>{{cite web|date = 18 November 2004|last = Harrison|first = Jeff|title = U.S. Wastes Half of Food Produced|url = http://uanews.org/node/10448|accessdate = 2010-03-07|postscript = <!-- None -->}}</ref> In many countries, charities collect excess food from supermarkets and restaurants and distribute it to impoverished neighbourhoods. Trash pickers, [[Karung guni]], [[Zabaleen]], and [[Rag and bone man|rag and bone men]] in these countries may concentrate on looking for usable items or scrap materials to sell rather than food items. In the United States, Canada, and Europe, some bakeries, [[Supermarket|grocery stores]], or restaurants will routinely donate food according to a [[Emerson Good Samaritan Food Donation Act|Good Samaritan Food Donation Act]], but more often, because of health laws or company policy, they are required to discard food items by the [[shelf life|expiration date]], because of overstock, being overly ripened, spoiled, cosmetically imperfect, or blemished. * '''Books and periodicals'''. As proof to publishing houses of unsold merchandise, booksellers will routinely remove the front covers of printed materials to render them destroyed prior to disposing of their remains in the garbage. Though readable, many damaged publications have disclaimers and legal notices against their existence or sale. * '''Irregular or damaged goods'''. [[Office]]s, [[factory|factories]], [[department store]]s, and other commercial establishments may equally throw out non-perishable items that are irregular, were returned, have minor damages, or are replaced by newer inventory. Many items tend to be in such a state of disrepair or cosmetically flawed that they will require some work to make the items functionally usable. For this reason, employees will at times intentionally destroy their items prior to being discarded to prevent them from being reused or resold. * '''Returned items'''. Manufacturers often find it cheaper to routinely discard items returned as defective under warranty instead of repairing them, although a device is often repairable or usable as a source of spare parts to repair other, similar discarded devices. * '''School Supplies'''. At the end of each school year many people throw away perfectly useful supplies like pencils, pens, notebooks, art supplies. * '''[[eWaste]]'''. Some [[consumer electronics]] are dumped because of their rapid depreciation, obsolescence, cost to repair, or expense to upgrade. Owners of functional computers may find it easier to dump them rather than donate because many nonprofit organizations and schools are unable, or unwilling, to work with used equipment<ref>{{Cite journal|date = 6 November 2003|last = Ha|first = Tanya|title = E-waste|url = http://abc.net.au/science/features/ewaste|accessdate = 2007-06-11|publisher = [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]|postscript = <!-- None -->}}</ref> Occasionally, vendors dispose of unsaleable, non-defective new merchandise as landfill. The [[Atari video game burial]] in [[Alamogordo, New Mexico]] after the [[North American video game crash of 1983]] is a well-known example; a 2014 excavation recovered about 1300 games for curation as museum exhibits or auction. * '''Clothing'''. While thrift stores routinely refuse used goods which they cannot cheaply and easily resell, the items which they do accept cost them nothing. There is therefore no shrinkage cost associated with discarding mendable garments, repairable appliances or even working donated items which are overstock or find no buyer after some arbitrary length of time. * '''Metal'''. Sometimes waste may contain recyclable [[metal]]s and materials that can be reused or sold to [[Recycling|recycling plants]] and scrap yards. The most common recyclable metals found are steel and aluminum.<ref>{{cite web|title=What metals can be recycled?|url=http://www.doitpoms.ac.uk/tlplib/recycling-metals/what.php|publisher=University Of Cambridge|accessdate=3 April 2015}}</ref> * '''Wood'''. Called '''urban lumberjacking''', to salvage wood either for home heating,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.motherearthnews.com/nature-and-environment/urban-lumberjack-zmaz81sozraw.aspx |title=Become an Urban Lumberjack |date=October 1981 |first=David |last=Markson |accessdate=January 5, 2016 |publisher=Mother Earth News |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304111136/http://www.motherearthnews.com/nature-and-environment/urban-lumberjack-zmaz81sozraw.aspx |archivedate=March 4, 2016 |url-status=dead }}</ref> or home construction projects.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sustainablog.org/2011/09/urban-lumberjack/|title=The Urban Lumberjack – The Accidental Eco-Warrior of the City|last=Sustainblog|first=|date=September 2011|website=Sustainblog|access-date=2017-03-30}}</ref>
=== Other sources ===
* '''Residential buildings'''. Clothing, furniture, appliances, and other housewares may be found at residential buildings. * '''College dormitories'''. Items may be found at colleges with dormitories at the end of the semester when students throw away many items such as furniture, clothes and electronics.<ref>{{cite web|date = 6 May 2011|last = Lawrence|first = Robyn Griggs|title = College Graduation Means Great Dumpster Diving|url = http://www.motherearthnews.com/natural-home-living/college-graduation-means-great-dumpster-diving.aspx|accessdate = 2012-11-07|postscript = <!-- None -->}}</ref>
== Notable instances ==
In the 1960s, [[Jerry Schneider]], using recovered [[instruction manual]]s from [[The Pacific Telephone & Telegraph Company]], used the company's own procedures to acquire hundreds of thousands of dollars' worth of [[telephone]] equipment over several years until his arrest.
The ''[[Castle Infinity]]'' videogame, after its shutdown in 2005, was brought back from the dead by a fan rescuing its [[server (computing)|server]]s from the trash.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://games.slashdot.org/games/05/06/21/0133233.shtml?tid=206&tid=209&tid=10 |title=Classic MMOG Raised From the Dead by Past Players - Slashdot |publisher=Games.slashdot.org |date=2005-06-21 |accessdate=2012-09-07}}</ref>
[[Food Not Bombs]] is an anti-hunger organization that gets a significant amount of its food from dumpster diving from the dumpsters at small markets and corporate grocery stores in the US and UK.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/08/15/AR2006081501248_pf.html |title=Diving for Dinner |publisher=washingtonpost.com<! |date=2006-08-16 |accessdate=2009-05-07 | first=Megan | last=Greenwell}}</ref>
In October 2013, in North [[London]], three men were arrested and charged under the [[Vagrancy Act 1824|1824 Vagrancy Act]] when they were caught taking discarded food: tomatoes, mushrooms, cheese and cakes from bins behind an [[Iceland (supermarket)|Iceland supermarket]]. The charges were dropped on 29 January 2014 after much public criticism<ref name=skipping>{{cite web|last=Saner |first=Emine |url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/shortcuts/2014/jan/29/skipping-food-waste-supermarkets-dumpster-diving |title=Skipping: is there anything wrong with taking the food that supermarkets throw away? |website=The Guardian |date=2009-12-22 |accessdate=30 January 2014}}</ref> as well as a request by Iceland's chief executive, Malcolm Walker.<ref name=case-dropped>{{cite web| url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/jan/29/why-iceland-wanted-bin-theft-case-dropped | title=Why Iceland wanted the bin theft case dropped |author=Malcolm Walker |website=The Guardian |date=2013-12-04 |accessdate=30 January 2014}}</ref>
== In popular culture ==
=== Books === * Author John Hoffman wrote two books based on his own dumpster-diving exploits: ''The Art and Science of Dumpster Diving'' (1993 ; {{ISBN|978-1-58160-550-1}}) and ''Dumpster Diving: The Advanced Course: How to Turn Other People's Trash into Money, Publicity, and Power'' (2002; {{ISBN|978-1-58160-369-9}}), and was featured in the documentary DVD ''The Ultimate Dive'', which was directed by Suzanne Girot and described by the [[Internet Movie Database]] as a "Tongue-in-cheek how-to film on the art and science of dumpster diving." * In 2001, dumpster diving was popularized in the book ''[[Evasion (book)|Evasion]],'' published by [[CrimethInc.]]<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.crimethinc.com/books/evasion.html |author=CrimethInc. contributor |year= 2001 |title= Evasion |publisher= [[CrimethInc.]] |accessdate= November 7, 2014 |quote= A 288 page novel-like narrative, ''Evasion'' is one person's travelogue of thievery and trespassing across the country, evading not only arrest, but also the 40-hour workweek and hopeless boredom of modern life. The journey documents a literal and metaphorical reclamation of an individual's life and the spaces surrounding them—scamming, squatting, dumpstering, train hopping and shoplifting... }}</ref> * In [[Kim Stanley Robinson]]'s science fiction novel ''[[Fifty Degrees Below]]'' (2005), the character Frank Vanderwal joins, for a time, a group of [[Freeganism|freegans]] (referred to as "fregans" in the novel) who frequently prepare feasts culled from dumpsters<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oGE9DwAAQBAJ&pg=PA191&dq=fifty+degrees+below+dumpster&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwitydeap6XgAhXF1FkKHZzuB0cQ6AEIKDAA#v=onepage&q=fifty%20degrees%20below%20dumpster&f=false|title=Fifty Degrees Below|last=Robinson|first=Kim Stanley|date=2005|publisher=Bantam Books|isbn=9780553803129|language=en}}</ref>; kind-hearted [[restaurateur]]s aid them by setting aside foods which have not been touched by the public. * Jeff Ferrell, Professor of Sociology at [[Texas Christian University]], is the author of ''Empire of Scrounge: Inside the Urban Underground of Dumpster Diving, Trash Picking, and Street Scavenging'' (2005; {{ISBN|978-0-81472-738-6}}). * [[Cory Doctorow]] integrated garbage picking characters into the plots of his novels ''[[Someone Comes to Town, Someone Leaves Town]]'' and ''[[Pirate Cinema (novel)|Pirate Cinema]]''.
=== Television programs ===
* British television shows have featured home renovations and decoration using salvaged materials. ''[[Changing Rooms (TV show)|Changing Rooms]]'' (1996-2004) is one such show, broadcast on [[BBC One]].
=== Films ===
* ''Surfing the Waste: A Musical Documentary About Dumpster Diving'', a film by Paul Aflalo, Sandra Lombardi and Tomoe Yoshihara, with music composed by [[Alden Penner]] and Nic Boshart.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nisimazine.eu/Surfing-the-Waste-A-Musical.html |author=Taborelli, Silvia |year=2008 |title=Surfing the Waste: A Musical Documentary about Dumpster Diving |publisher=NISI MASA, European Network of Young Cinema |accessdate=November 7, 2014 |quote=Liz, Mike, Allison, Owain and Alden are five youngsters living in Montreal. They dance, sing and play in this upbeat short film which tells about "dumpster diving". It may sound like a sport, but it's actually a way of life. |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141107141352/http://www.nisimazine.eu/Surfing-the-Waste-A-Musical.html |archivedate=November 7, 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.indyish.com/surfing-the-waste-making-its-world-premiere-at-idfa-2008/ |author= Aflalo, Paul |date= November 25, 2008 |title= Surfing the Waste, making it's World Premiere at IDFA 2008 |publisher= Indyish |accessdate= November 7, 2014}}</ref> * ''Dumpster Wars: Reno's Trash Politics'' (2008)<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.saverenodumpsterdiving.com/ |title= One Man's Trash is Another Man's Treasure |website= [[Reno Gazette-Journal]] |accessdate= November 7, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last= Fortenbury |first= Jon |title= Diving Team: Come on in, the Dumpster's fine |work= NewsReview |date= May 26, 2011 |url= http://www.newsreview.com/reno/diving-team/content?oid=2148534 |accessdate= November 7, 2014}}</ref> * ''I Love Trash'' (2007), a 30-minute documentary by David Brown and Greg Mann. [[OCLC]]'s [[WorldCat]] provided a synopsis: "''I Love Trash'' is a documentary about the art of dumpster diving. Starting with an empty apartment, only the clothes they were wearing and a flashlight, David and Greg find everything they might otherwise buy, in trash cans and dumpsters. All their food, clothes, electronics, art materials and entertainment, all out of the trash."<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.worldcat.org/title/i-love-trash/oclc/232360707 |author= [[WorldCat]] |year= 2007 |title= I Love Trash |publisher= [[OCLC]] |accessdate= November 7, 2014}}</ref> Accolades: Skyfest Film and Script Festival, (won 2nd place for Documentary Films<ref>{{cite web |url= http://skyfest.net/index.php?id=79 |author= Skyfest |year= 2007 |title= Feature Documentary: ''I Love Trash'' |publisher= Skyfest Film and Script Festival |accessdate= November 7, 2014}}</ref>); and Lake Michigan Film Competition, (won 3rd place for Documentary films).<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.greenplanetfilms.org/product/i-love-trash/ |author= Skyfest Film & Script Festival |year= 2007 |title= Winners SkyFest I |publisher= Green Planet Films |accessdate= November 7, 2014}}</ref> * The 2010 documentary film ''[[Dive! (film)|Dive!]]'', a short documentary written and directed by Jeremy Seifert, investigates dumpster diving in the Los Angeles area.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.divethefilm.com/ |author= Seifert, Jeremy |year= 2010 |title= Dive! |publisher= Compeller Pictures |accessdate= November 7, 2014 |quote= Inspired by a curiosity about our country's careless habit of sending food straight to landfills, the multi award-winning documentary ''DIVE!'' follows filmmaker Jeremy Seifert and friends as they dumpster-dive in the back alleys and gated garbage receptacles of Los Angeles' supermarkets. In the process, they salvage thousands of dollars worth of good, edible food... Winner of 21 Awards by Festivals Worldwide.}}</ref> ''Dive!'' premiered in October 2009 at the Gig Harbor Film Festival, where it won the Audience Choice Award. It has gone on to win awards at many other film festivals, including Best Documentary at the [[DC Independent Film Festival]] and Best Film at the Dutch Environmental Film Festival. * ''Spoils: Extraordinary Harvest''. A [[short film]]/[[mystery film]] and documentary by Alex Mallis. (2012) Accolades: Official Selection, [[New Orleans Film Festival]]. Official Selection, [[Independent Film Festival of Boston]]. Official Selection, [[DOC NYC]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.analectfilms.com/spoils/ |author= Mallis, Alex |year= 2012 |title= ''Spoils: Extraordinary Harvest'' |publisher= Analect Films |accessdate= November 7, 2014 |quote= Emulating the tradition of American Direct Cinema, filmmaker Alex Mallis captures intimate portraits of the divers, illuminating a practice as old as agriculture. Mallis' fly-on-the-wall access to these Brooklynites bring us along for a journey through the culture of dumpster diving, offering an unvarnished glimpse into one night of urban harvest.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://thinkprogress.org/climate/2012/11/21/1227001/spoils-film-documents-americans-who-reap-an-extraordinary-harvest/ |author= Lacey, Stephen |date= November 21, 2012 |title= Spoils: Film Documents Americans Who Reap An 'Extraordinary Harvest' From Waste |website= [[ThinkProgress]] |accessdate= November 7, 2014}}</ref> * ''The Leftovers: A Documentary about People Who Eat Trash'' (2008), a 28-minute [[Cinema of Sweden|Swedish]] documentary by Michael Cavanagh and Kerstin Übelacker.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.theleftovers.net/ |author= A WG Film Production |year= 2008 |title= A Recycled Road Trip |publisher= theleftovers.net |accessdate= November 7, 2014 |quote= A group of five diverse people have challenged themselves to drive 2000 km down the east coast of Australia in a veggie oil powered van, living on nothing but waste. With zero money but plenty of passion they put both themselves and society to the test.}}</ref> Mykel Bently, Paul Hood, Krystal Trickey, Nick Gill, and Sofia Arborelius (the latter two were [[Student exchange program|exchange students]]) joined together for this dumpster diver adventure. * ''From Dumpster To Dinner Plate'' (2011), an award-winning New Zealand [[short film|short]] documentary directed by Vanessa Hudson. "As the cost of food reaches record highs an underground movement of dumpster divers is rapidly gaining momentum fuelled by consumers who are forced to find creative ways to feed themselves."<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.fromdumpstertodinnerplate.com/ |year= 2011 |title= From Dumpster To Dinner Plate |publisher= fromdumpstertodinnerplate.com/ |accessdate= November 7, 2014}}</ref>
